content:
I've changed the Constrains.
They were:
0 ≤ [[N]] ≤ 100000000000
I've changed to:
1 ≤ [[N]] length ≤ 11

Reasoning:

Your tests do not cover one corner case of 100000000000. That is crucial because the shortest solution known to me is:
p (gets.to_i(2)^m=682)-m (Ruby; credit to TheCrucial)
But it wouldn't work for 100000000000. And old constrains are saying that 100000000000 is possible so it shouldn't be getting 100%.

N=0 is not possible because "Input negative binary number always starts with '1' (at the top digit)."

Also, it's not so clear if it is in bit or dec or negative dec.

And N is a string. It's not js so you can't compare strings.

Was semi-confusing at first. I personally think a bit more clarification on how the system works would be very beneficial. Additionally, if you're going to require the person to (eventually) read a number larger than an integer, you should set the stub generator to signify this, either change the way the input is read to either be a double or string please.

Other than that, perfectly fine suggestion and would be happy to have this as a clash.

I changed the input into a string.
I will try to clarify it a bit more, however part of the task is to understand how numeral systems work, and it tests it too :).
Thank you for the ideas.
